page.title: 04LACROSSE IN STOCKPORT AREA
page.content: Lacrosse is a strenuous game for 11 players which originates from the Iroquois tribe of Indians in N.America. A small ball is passed between players using a special stick with a net or "crosse" on the end in which to carry the ball,until a goal is scored. Protective equipment is required. A helmet and gloves are compulsory but players also wear arm and shoulder pads. The game has been played in Stockport (the major Lacrosse area in the North of England) since before 1940, but today only about 1000 men play in N.England and most top level players are over 30 years old. The game is in danger of dying out although there are 11 mens teams throughout Stockport and Cheadle. There is also a game called Womens' Lacrosse in which there are more rules but no equipment.
